repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
## Problem

help.c is hard to maintain with multiple functions spanning over 200 LOC and a lot of manual string replacing/pattern finding. As mentioned in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/36249#issuecomment-3425235876, refactoring (parts of) the help system to Lua is a good step to modularizing the help system in order to work with different backends.

## Solution

Start with moving the logic of escaping the argument `{subject}` to Lua. Later PRs will cover other parts of the help system.


Potential follow-up: Eliminate the "exception" table.

comment_data.body: straight up from test/old/testdir/help_test_tagjump.vim. Should I remove them there?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -13,6 +14,71 @@ local write_file = t.write_file
 describe(':help', function()
   before_each(clear)
 
+  it('{subject} works', function()
+    local function check_tag(cmd, tag)
+      n.command(cmd)
+      -- eq('help', eval('&filetype'))
+      expect_any(tag)
+      n.command('helpclose')
+    end
+
+    check_tag([[help]], [[*help.txt*]])
+    check_tag([[help |]], [[*bar*]])
+    check_tag([[help "]], [[*quote*]])
+    check_tag([[help *]], [[*star*]])
+    check_tag([[help "*]], [[*quotestar*]])
+    check_tag([[help ch?ckhealth]], [[*:checkhealth*]])
+    check_tag([[help ??]], [[*??*]])
+    check_tag([[help :?]], [[*:?*]])
+    check_tag([[help q?]], [[*q?*]])
+    check_tag([[help -?]], [[*-?*]])
+    check_tag([[help v_g?]], [[*v_g?*]])
+    check_tag([[help expr-!=?]], [[*expr-!=?*]])
+    check_tag([[help expr-isnot?]], [[*expr-isnot?*]])
+    check_tag([[help FileW*Post]], [[*FileWritePost*]])
+    check_tag([[help `ls`]], [[*:ls*]])
+    check_tag([[help ^X]], [[*CTRL-X*]])
+    check_tag([[help i^X]], [[*i_CTRL-X*]])
+    check_tag([[help i_^X]], [[*i_CTRL-X*]])
+    check_tag([[help i_^_CTRL-D]], [[*i_^_CTRL-D*]])
+    check_tag([[help i^G^J]], [[i_CTRL-G_CTRL-J]])
+    check_tag([[help i^x^y]], [[*i_CTRL-X_CTRL-Y*]])
+    check_tag([[help /\|]], [[*/\bar*]])
+    check_tag([[help \_$]], [[*/\_$*]])
+    check_tag([[help CTRL-\_CTRL-N]], [[*CTRL-\_CTRL-N*]])
+    check_tag([[help `:pwd`,]], [[*:pwd*]])
+    check_tag([[help `:ls`.]], [[*:ls*]])
+
+    check_tag([[help \S]], [[/\S]])
+    check_tag([[help \{]], [[/\{]])
+    check_tag([[help \_$]], [[/\_$]])

comment_data.body:
It might be simpler to first convert `i^X` to `iCTRL-X` and then `iCTRL-X` to `i_CTRL-X`. Feels a bit hacky but simplifies the code quite a bit. What do you think?

```lua
word = word:gsub('%^([^_])', 'CTRL-%1')
word = word:gsub('([^_\\])CTRL%-', '%1_CTRL-')
word = word:gsub('(CTRL%-.)([^_\\])', '%1_%2')
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,175 @@
+local M = {}
+
+local tag_exceptions = {
+  ['*'] = 'star',
+  ['g*'] = 'gstar',
+  ['[*'] = '[star',
+  [']*'] = ']star',
+  [':*'] = ':star',
+  ['/*'] = '/star',
+  ['/\\*'] = '/\\\\star',
+  ['"*'] = 'quotestar',
+  ['**'] = 'starstar',
+  ['cpo-*'] = 'cpo-star',
+  ['/\\(\\)'] = '/\\\\(\\\\)',
+  ['/\\%(\\)'] = '/\\\\%(\\\\)',
+  ['?'] = '?',
+  ['??'] = '??',
+  [':?'] = ':?',
+  ['?<CR>'] = '?<CR>',
+  ['g?'] = 'g?',
+  ['g?g?'] = 'g?g?',
+  ['g??'] = 'g??',
+  ['-?'] = '-?',
+  ['q?'] = 'q?',
+  ['v_g?'] = 'v_g?',
+  ['/\\?'] = '/\\\\?',
+  ['/\\z(\\)'] = '/\\\\z(\\\\)',
+  ['\\='] = '\\\\=',
+  [':s\\='] = ':s\\\\=',
+  ['[count]'] = '\\[count]',
+  ['[quotex]'] = '\\[quotex]',
+  ['[range]'] = '\\[range]',
+  [':[range]'] = ':\\[range]',
+  ['[pattern]'] = '\\[pattern]',
+  ['\\|'] = '\\\\bar',
+  ['\\%$'] = '/\\\\%\\$',
+  ['s/\\~'] = 's/\\\\\\~',
+  ['s/\\U'] = 's/\\\\U',
+  ['s/\\L'] = 's/\\\\L',
+  ['s/\\1'] = 's/\\\\1',
+  ['s/\\2'] = 's/\\\\2',
+  ['s/\\3'] = 's/\\\\3',
+  ['s/\\9'] = 's/\\\\9',
+  ['expr-!=?'] = '!=?',
+  ['expr-!~?'] = '!\\~?',
+  ['expr-<=?'] = '<=?',
+  ['expr-<?'] = '<?',
+  ['expr-==?'] = '==?',
+  ['expr-=~?'] = '=~?',
+  ['expr->=?'] = '>=?',
+  ['expr->?'] = '>?',
+  ['expr-is?'] = 'is?',
+  ['expr-isnot?'] = 'isnot?',
+}
+
+---@param word string
+---@return string
+function M.escape_subject(word)
+  local replacement = tag_exceptions[word]
+  if replacement then
+    return replacement
+  end
+
+  -- Add prefix "/\\" to patterns starting with a backslash
+  -- Examples: \S, \%^, \%(, \zs, \z1, \@<, \@=, \@<=, \_$, \_^
+  if word:match([[^\.$]]) or word:match('^\\[%%_z@]') then
+    word = [[/\]] .. word
+    word = word:gsub('[$.~]', [[\%0]])
+  else
+    -- Fix for bracket expressions and curly braces:
+    -- "\" becomes "\\" (needs to come first)
+    -- "[:" becomes "\[:" (escape the opening bracket)
+    -- "[++" becomes "\[++" (for command options)
+    -- "\{" becomes "\\{" (for help on \{ pattern matching)
+    -- "(" becomes "" (parentheses around option tags should be ignored)
+    word = word:gsub([[\]], [[\\]])
+    word = word:gsub([[^%[:]], [[\[:]])
+    word = word:gsub([[^%[%+%+]], [[\[++]])
+    word = word:gsub([[^\{]], [[\\{]])
+    word = word:gsub([[^%(']], [[']])
+
+    word = word:gsub([[|]], 'bar')
+    word = word:gsub([["]], 'quote')
+    word = word:gsub('[$.~]', [[\%0]])
+    word = word:gsub([[%*]], [[.*]])
+    word = word:gsub([[?]], [[.]])
+
+    -- TODO: also actual CTRL character 0x01
+    -- "i^G^J" --> "i_CTRL-G-CTRL-J"
+    -- In a repeat because string.gsub doesn't handle overlapping patterns, which can happen with
+    -- i^G^J where before="^", ctrl_char="G", and after="^".
+    local count
+    repeat
+      -- Capture three chars in this pattern: {char}^{char}{char}
+      word, count = word:gsub('(.?)%^([^_])(.?)', function (before, ctrl_char, after)
+        local result = 'CTRL-' .. ctrl_char
+        if before ~= '' and before ~= '_' and before ~= '\\' then
+          result = '_' .. result
+        end
+        if after ~= '' and after ~= '_' and after ~= '\\' then
+          result = result .. '_'
+        end
+        return before .. result .. after
+      end)
+    until count == 0

 describe(':help', function()
   before_each(clear)
 
+  it('{subject} works', function()

+      n.command('helpclose')
+    end
+
+    check_tag([[help]], [[*help.txt*]])
+    check_tag([[help |]], [[*bar*]])
+    check_tag([[help "]], [[*quote*]])
+    check_tag([[help *]], [[*star*]])
+    check_tag([[help "*]], [[*quotestar*]])
+    check_tag([[help ch?ckhealth]], [[*:checkhealth*]])
+    check_tag([[help ??]], [[*??*]])
+    check_tag([[help :?]], [[*:?*]])
+    check_tag([[help q?]], [[*q?*]])
+    check_tag([[help -?]], [[*-?*]])
+    check_tag([[help v_g?]], [[*v_g?*]])
+    check_tag([[help expr-!=?]], [[*expr-!=?*]])
+    check_tag([[help expr-isnot?]], [[*expr-isnot?*]])
+    check_tag([[help FileW*Post]], [[*FileWritePost*]])
+    check_tag([[help `ls`]], [[*:ls*]])
+    check_tag([[help ^X]], [[*CTRL-X*]])
+    check_tag([[help i^X]], [[*i_CTRL-X*]])
+    check_tag([[help i_^X]], [[*i_CTRL-X*]])
+    check_tag([[help i_^_CTRL-D]], [[*i_^_CTRL-D*]])
+    check_tag([[help i^G^J]], [[i_CTRL-G_CTRL-J]])
+    check_tag([[help i^x^y]], [[*i_CTRL-X_CTRL-Y*]])
+    check_tag([[help /\|]], [[*/\bar*]])
+    check_tag([[help \_$]], [[*/\_$*]])
+    check_tag([[help CTRL-\_CTRL-N]], [[*CTRL-\_CTRL-N*]])
+    check_tag([[help `:pwd`,]], [[*:pwd*]])
+    check_tag([[help `:ls`.]], [[*:ls*]])
+
+    check_tag([[help \S]], [[/\S]])
+    check_tag([[help \{]], [[/\{]])
+    check_tag([[help \_$]], [[/\_$]])

comment_data.body: sure, the more readable version is fine. the main thing is to have test cases with lots of input => output examples. then we can always change the approach later if needed.

+local M = {}
+
+local tag_exceptions = {
+  ['*'] = 'star',
+  ['g*'] = 'gstar',
+  ['[*'] = '[star',
+  [']*'] = ']star',
+  [':*'] = ':star',

+  ['?'] = '?',

+  ['?<CR>'] = '?<CR>',
+  ['g?'] = 'g?',
+  ['g?g?'] = 'g?g?',
+  ['g??'] = 'g??',
+  ['-?'] = '-?',
+  ['q?'] = 'q?',
+  ['v_g?'] = 'v_g?',
+  ['/\\?'] = '/\\\\?',
+  ['/\\z(\\)'] = '/\\\\z(\\\\)',
+  ['\\='] = '\\\\=',
+  [':s\\='] = ':s\\\\=',
+  ['[count]'] = '\\[count]',
+  ['[quotex]'] = '\\[quotex]',
+  ['[range]'] = '\\[range]',
+  [':[range]'] = ':\\[range]',
+  ['[pattern]'] = '\\[pattern]',
+  ['\\|'] = '\\\\bar',
+  ['\\%$'] = '/\\\\%\\$',
+  ['s/\\~'] = 's/\\\\\\~',
+  ['s/\\U'] = 's/\\\\U',
+  ['s/\\L'] = 's/\\\\L',
+  ['s/\\1'] = 's/\\\\1',
+  ['s/\\2'] = 's/\\\\2',
+  ['s/\\3'] = 's/\\\\3',
+  ['s/\\9'] = 's/\\\\9',
+  ['expr-!=?'] = '!=?',
+  ['expr-!~?'] = '!\\~?',
+  ['expr-<=?'] = '<=?',
+  ['expr-<?'] = '<?',
+  ['expr-==?'] = '==?',
+  ['expr-=~?'] = '=~?',
+  ['expr->=?'] = '>=?',
+  ['expr->?'] = '>?',
+  ['expr-is?'] = 'is?',
+  ['expr-isnot?'] = 'isnot?',
+}
+
+---@param word string
+---@return string
+function M.escape_subject(word)
+  local replacement = tag_exceptions[word]
+  if replacement then
+    return replacement
+  end
+
+  -- Add prefix "/\\" to patterns starting with a backslash
+  -- Examples: \S, \%^, \%(, \zs, \z1, \@<, \@=, \@<=, \_$, \_^
+  if word:match([[^\.$]]) or word:match('^\\[%%_z@]') then
+    word = [[/\]] .. word
+    word = word:gsub('[$.~]', [[\%0]])
+  else
+    -- Fix for bracket expressions and curly braces:
+    -- "\" becomes "\\" (needs to come first)
+    -- "[:" becomes "\[:" (escape the opening bracket)
+    -- "[++" becomes "\[++" (for command options)
+    -- "\{" becomes "\\{" (for help on \{ pattern matching)
+    -- "(" becomes "" (parentheses around option tags should be ignored)
+    word = word:gsub([[\]], [[\\]])
+    word = word:gsub([[^%[:]], [[\[:]])
+    word = word:gsub([[^%[%+%+]], [[\[++]])
+    word = word:gsub([[^\{]], [[\\{]])
+    word = word:gsub([[^%(']], [[']])
+
+    word = word:gsub([[|]], 'bar')
+    word = word:gsub([["]], 'quote')
+    word = word:gsub('[$.~]', [[\%0]])
+    word = word:gsub([[%*]], [[.*]])
+    word = word:gsub([[?]], [[.]])
+
+    -- TODO: also actual CTRL character 0x01
+    -- "i^G^J" --> "i_CTRL-G-CTRL-J"
+    -- In a repeat because string.gsub doesn't handle overlapping patterns, which can happen with
+    -- i^G^J where before="^", ctrl_char="G", and after="^".
+    local count
+    repeat
+      -- Capture three chars in this pattern: {char}^{char}{char}
+      word, count = word:gsub('(.?)%^([^_])(.?)', function (before, ctrl_char, after)
+        local result = 'CTRL-' .. ctrl_char
+        if before ~= '' and before ~= '_' and before ~= '\\' then
+          result = '_' .. result
+        end
+        if after ~= '' and after ~= '_' and after ~= '\\' then
+          result = result .. '_'
+        end
+        return before .. result .. after
+      end)
+    until count == 0

comment_data.body: Hm good point. "Old tests" signaled to me they would need to be replaced by (Lua) tests eventually and having them in two places seems redundant

comment_data.body:
puc lua is more strict that luajit, that's probably the cause of this CI failure.

```
test/functional/ex_cmds/help_spec.lua:24: bad argument #4 to 'format' (string expected, got boolean)

stack traceback:
	test/functional/ex_cmds/help_spec.lua:24: in function 'check_tag'
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -13,6 +13,114 @@ local write_file = t.write_file
 describe(':help', function()
   before_each(clear)
 
+  it('{subject}', function()
+    n.command('helptags ++t $VIMRUNTIME/doc')
+    local function check_tag(cmd, tag)
+      local cmd_ok = t.pcall(n.command, cmd)
+      local found = n.api.nvim_get_current_line():find(tag, 1, true)
+      local errmsg = (not cmd_ok and 'command failed') or (not found and 'tag not found')
+      assert(
+        cmd_ok and found,
+        string.format('Expected `:%s` to jump to tag `%s`, but %s', cmd, tag, errmsg)

comment_data.body:
ensure string

```suggestion
      local errmsg = (not cmd_ok and 'command failed') or (not found and 'tag not found') or '?'
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -13,6 +13,114 @@ local write_file = t.write_file
 describe(':help', function()
   before_each(clear)
 
+  it('{subject}', function()
+    n.command('helptags ++t $VIMRUNTIME/doc')
+    local function check_tag(cmd, tag)
+      local cmd_ok = t.pcall(n.command, cmd)
+      local found = n.api.nvim_get_current_line():find(tag, 1, true)
+      local errmsg = (not cmd_ok and 'command failed') or (not found and 'tag not found')

comment_regular_data.body: glad to see this, i wasn't happy about increasing our C debt in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/36205 . so I will wait on this instead.
Marking this as ready for review now. I'm not sure if the CI will pass, as [GitHub CI seems to be down](https://www.githubstatus.com/), will fix otherwise.

I can reproduce the installation problems that arise on CI:

```
$ ./build/bin/nvim -u NONE -e -c 'help' -c 'qall'
```

Only happens when `VIMRUNTIME` is not specified (hence why I didn't see the error originally on my own machine).

Gives the error that `vim._core.help` is not found. @justinmk do I need to register `vim._core.help` somewhere in the build files?

> do I need to register `vim._core.help` somewhere in the build files?

not usually, `_core/*` is [globbed](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/54468c1c3c2e412e5e0d714101cdfbb44ae4600a/src/nvim/CMakeLists.txt#L354-L355). there are some special cases [here](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/54468c1c3c2e412e5e0d714101cdfbb44ae4600a/src/nvim/lua/executor.c#L2153-L2157) but that should rarely be needed.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

labels.description: changes that are not features or bugfixes
labels.name: refactor

title: refactor(help): move escaping logic to Lua
